With Wicked, what you see is what you get. The setting is fantastic, the cast is phenomenal, and the musical numbers are mesmerizing. The world of Oz feels much more populated than the original film might lead you to believe. It also feels like an actual governed society instead of some outlandish fantasy world. Cynthia Erivo did a great job as Elphaba and gives a convincing performance, but Ariana Grande stole the show for me. She embodied her role so whole-heartedly; I forget that she isn't actually like that in person. Her comedy in this movie was priceless (for me, at least). It was exactly my kind of humor. I chuckled here more than any other movie this year. The story was pretty basic. It's the same old "misunderstood villain" schtick that I've grown tired of, but the B-Plot was very interesting. I hope that it gets elaborated upon going forward. And yes, this is only Part One. They have more story yet to tell. I found it more entertaining than I expected it to be. 4 out of 5.

I am a huge fan of the novel series by Gregory Maguire, and therefore rolled my eyes at the announcement of the movie that promised to be an adaptation of the stage everyone loved, as opposed to the darker and more sinister (and nuanced I felt) novel series. However, I did drag myself to the theater to watch it with a friend, if only to bemuse them, and despite a first watch being distracted by a horribly distracted audience experience (people were standing up and feuding over children making too much noise) upon a second watching, I did, in fact, fall in love. What neysayers are possibly missing, and perhaps don‚Äôt want, is a more grounded story. Well, read the novels, I would say to that. But for this musical, for this adaptation, and for mainly the characters of Galinda/Glinda and Elphaba, Jon M Chu successfully inserted just enough more nuance and character development to make this, honestly, superior to the stage experience. If you want the glitz and glam and stage craft, absolutely see the stage play. Short, sweet, to the point. It gets the message more or less across of ‚Äògirl discriminated against because she is different, meets people along the way, becomes bitter, and falls in love and, well the story (and my memory) gets fuzzy toward the end but whatever don‚Äôt think about it.‚Äô What the movie does is it takes that raw story, takes even more of the aesthetic of the 1939 film than Gregory Maguire, in a written medium, was able to infuse, and sets all of that ablaze with the looks that Ariana Granda and Cynthia Erivo conjure between one another and those on the periphery that inform their tale. Truly spell binding, with engaging choreography and enough detail that it warrants multiple watches, and while you are searching for each new moment, you get to once again listen to Cynthia belt ‚Äòthe wizard and I‚Äô, unknowingly joke about her tragic fate of melting, and be excited to meet the man that will ultimately cause her revolt and ultimate disappointment, and Ariana‚Äôs ability to act priveledged, but simultaneously show the truth behind Gregory Maguires character of Glinda, which is more that she never had the opportunity to think before meeting Elphaba, and though it is startling, Glinda does ultimately happily rise to the challenge. Again, magnificent and spellbinding. Thank you, John M Chu, and I‚Äôm still waiting for that stupid picnic deleted scene!

Was excited for this, but it was a bit of a letdown. Highlights are Jonathan Bailey's Fiyero and Michelle Yeoh's Madame Morrible, as well as the background actors performances. Costuming is by-and-large great as well, albeit with a few notable flops. Sets are mostly good, but the overuse of CGI really holds a lot of scenes back. Its glaringly obvious in quite a few scenes and makes several big moments just look silly - I really wish they had used more practical effects. And the music is mostly good too, though the unnecesarry riffs from both leads do take away from it at times... But most of the issue is with the acting - apart from a couple standouts, it is just a mess. Elphaba and Glinda's dynamic should be the centerpoint of this story, but despite all their time together, they just dont sell that - every interaction between them feels forced and fake. I didnt expect them to fully live up to their brodway counterparts, but I was at least expecting them to look like they genuinely care about each other by the end... Boq also gets a strange amount of screentime for such a minor character, and is never fun to watch. While Nessa doesnt get enough to feel like a meaningful character, which will certainly hamper the second half.

o Though a bit confusing in the early going, "Wicked" ended up being well scripted, well acted, with great effects, and some wonderful voices. The two principals were amazing as was Goldblum who carried off his number with style. I had never considered him a singer before seeing this but he performed marvelously. Michelle Yeoh was wonderful as was the entire supporting cast. The cinematography was spectacular and the sound recording and editing was as good as it should be for a musical presentation. I have been a fan of the Wizard of Oz since first seeing it when I was eight. The most impressive character was the Wicked Witch of the West played by Margaret Hamilton. Cynthia Erivo honored Hamilton with her portrayal of this character. The story was well designed - the writers found a way to take us back to before Dorothy while recalling the original story. A real winner that I would give a higher score to it, if I could, but I found it too operetta-like in some cases. Script was sung that would have been better left as spoken dialogue. If not for that, the movie would deserve five stars but because of that I can only give it four and a half. But, it's definitely worth the watch. Summary: A great musical.

My overall first impressions was I did not like this movie. But I went into this with ideas based on what I could remember of the Wizard of Oz, and so it was hard for me to readjust my perception on who I thought was going to be "wicked" and who was not. And even when I it dawned on me who I was supposed to like and dislike, that too took another turn. I think in hindsight, had I been informed about what the Broadway version of this story was all about I would've been more accommodating. But putting that aside, I also found the songs to be for want of a better word "off-key". A lot of the notes just keep going in the wrong direction for me, and I found that I could not hum along. I like musicals that have songs that are easy to pick up and for some reason I could not do it here. So, that was enough for me to be meh about the movie. But, if I was to analyse this movie from a critical perspective I'd have to say the casting was just sublime - from the somewhat shallow, but on the very edge of breaking through into someone of substance Galinda, to the enigmatic and charming, but ultimately serving no real purpose at all Oz. And though I have no love for the songs, they were delivered with great emphasis. And the stage settings were very innovative and a delight to look at. It just bugs me that on this occasion, reading a synopsis of the Broadway Version might have made a difference for me.

Fantastic movie. Everything from the sets and costumes, to the actors and musical performances are stunning. Music obviously is great. Loved the story when seeing it on stage, and it's not like they changed that. However something about it doesn't really work. I get it, it has hype and everyone is supposed to love it. Maybe if you haven't seen it on stage it's spectacular. Maybe it's the same concept as "the book is better", but the film just doesn't have the magic. The acting is underwhelming. Ariana is the best, however it just feels like she's doing a Kristen Chenoweth impersonation the whole time. She didn't make the character her own, maybe she would have failed if she tried, so it's a bit of stacked deck either way. As far as Cynthia goes, her first song made me think "why didn't they get a professional singer?", then I looked her up and was shocked. She clearly has the singing pedigree so it has to be something with stage singing not translating to film, or the sound recording. There's just something off with her solos. Visually it's nothing special, CGI is average at best. Overall the film is just underwhelming. End of the day, it's fine to experience the story and music if you can't see it on stage or if live musicals aren't your thing, but the film doesn't hold a candle to a live performance. Other Broadway to films have been done successfully, this one just falls short. This is ok for a one time watch, but repeated watches would be a task, especially at 2 hour 40 minutes. My husband was moved by this, I however was left cold. I love the book and enjoyed the musical, unfortunately this had neither the depth of the former nor the simplicity of the latter. Hollywood has taken a great book and a clever musical and as is it's wont, managed to make worst of both! The storyline is a mangled confusion of the two, resulting in an uncomfortable mix of political fable and Musical. Yes the sets are impressive, rich, and complex, but after half an hour or so one is so overwhelmed by them and the colour saturation (presumably a reflection of the Garland film in Technicolor) that a rest in a darkened room may be advised. And the two main characters are woefully miscast. Cynthia's Elphaba is, unbelievably given she's green, unmemorable. The book describes her as an independent feisty, deeply political creature, whereas Cynthia's portrayal seems to be of a slightly wet and insecure girl. And AG's Glinda is so robotic she may as well be AI! The book describes her as charismatic, but selfish and bitchy with a sharp and witty tongue. AG is none of this. They both lack charm and screen presence and for me, despite the fact that they're the only two students not in uniform, they almost blend into the over blown background. All in all a disappointment.

This movie fails at everything it tries to do. The runtime is simply unacceptable and the movie is filled with Hollywood bloat. Copius needless dialogue scenes added with the characters taking significantly large (7-10 second) pauses between each line so the generic Hollywood score has time to play and tell the audience what emotion they're supposed to feel. Neither Cynthia Erivo nor Ariana Grande seems willing to give their all to their characters, with Ariana's poor acting being a particularly sore spot of the movie. The aesthetic of the movie leans towards plastic, fake, and overly CGI'd, completely losing any sense of immersion. The lighting is particularly dreadful and does nothing to support the story or the emotions of the scene. (The lighting for the final scene, in particular, is very bad.) The pacing is horrid. The movie lurches from slow dialogue scene to slow dialogue scene, occasionally grinding inexplicably to a halt to begrudgingly shoehorn in one of the songs from the musical that it attempts to pay homage to. The musical numbers are so underwhelmingly choreographed and shot, with two of the biggest and most iconic numbers in the show sharing the exact same setting and color palette (their shared dorm room). All this pales in comparison to how they murdered "Defying Gravity", which was all I was holding out to hear after over two and a half hours of stupid Hollywood slop. They insisted on chopping the song up into sections so they could continually cut away from it, completely stop the song to switch back to the generic Hollywood score, add fake tension to a scene that didn't need it, then once again come back and remember they're supposed to be singing literally the showstopping number. It's like if Les Miserables kept stopping "One Day More" to show you footage from The Wire. Just terrible. This movie didn't even deserve to play the songs from the musical which it so wickedly massacred. Prior to watching this, I had thought I might at least sit through Part II to hear For Good, but now knowing how poorly they executed Part I, it's not worth my time or money. I'll just put on the OBC soundtrack.

Cynthia Erivo, as Elphaba, did a fantastic action. She makes the character real, and her singing is so powerful. I have goosebumps and cry when hearing Defying Gravity at the movie's end. Ariana Grande, as Glinda, her character is funny, but when she sings, her emotions go with it. When Cynthia and Ariana sing together, they make it more perfect and act like real friends. Their feelings and friendship are realistic. The Original Soundtracks are way better than Disney movies these days. They are all good. I‚Äôve listened to the original musical, and I like the movie version more. I personally like Defying Gravity, which makes me emotional; Dancing Through Life and Popular is a fun song. The Wizard And I has a great high note at the end; and One Short Day, featuring Idina Menzel, Kristin Chenoweth, and the original cast from the musical version of Frozen. Wicked is a prequel to The Wizard of Oz but focuses on how Elphaba becomes The Wicked Witch of the West. The story is about Elphaba and Glinda's friendship. They met at Shiz University in the Oz. Animals can talk and teach in the university, but the plot twist is that The Wizard of Oz is not a good person. He wants those animals to be blamed so he can continue controlling Oz. Still, Elphaba knows this and resists it by stealing the grimmer, the magical spell book, and becoming The Wicked Witch to resist The Wizard. Her relationship with Glinda reaches a crossroads as they take different paths. Even though the movie is 160 minutes long, I don‚Äôt get bored at all. Every moment and every action is worth watching. The CG is excellent. I watched it in IMAX, and the sound, the songs, everything feels so real. This is the first time I've watched such a great musical movie. Part 2 will be released on November 21 this year, and I will absolutely watch it. I‚Äôve listened to the song For Good from Part 2, and its meaning really touches me. The people who said Wicked shouldn‚Äôt won the Oscar are biased and mad because their favorite movie didn‚Äôt win. Wicked deserves an Oscar, the reviews from critics and audiences are above 80%. This is one of the highest-rated movies in 2024 and the highest-rated musical movies in 2024. The whole song from Wicked debuts on the Billboard 200 charts, no other film can do this. This proves that Wicked deserves an Oscar.

Marissa Bode was really good too, and poignant as the girl confined to a wheelchair.. Loved the animals, especially the goat professor, and their subplot: the stormtroopers dragging him out from the lecture hall gave a jolt, specially given our current political reality, and the campaign for ethical treatment of animals! Wicked has a lot going for it. There are plenty of catchy tunes. Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo give remarkable performances. The sets, make-up, and cinematography make for some great eye candy. Despite all of that, there are some questions to be asked. The play ran for 150 minutes. Why is the first HALF of the film franchise longer than the entire play? There‚Äôs a lot of filler that could be trimmed, but two movies are clearly twice as profitable for the studio, one would suppose. Why does pretty much the whole thing look as though it was shot in the gloom of Hogwarts instead of the colorful and vibrant Oz from The Wizard of Oz? Why are virtually all of the Munchkins taller than Glinda? Why must the movie (and the play and the book) change our view of the Wicked Witch from inherently evil to a victim of her social circumstances? And, really, why does it need ‚Äúto be continued‚Äù?

Contrary to what certain memes suggests, it is in fact possible to spoil an adaptation of an old/well-known property, so I won‚Äôt be ruining any surprises here, even if to a large number of folks, they aren‚Äôt really surprising. Although, mild spoiler for the spoilers (spoilception?) there are quite a few surprises. Chu‚Äôs take on the smash Broadway adaptation of the bestselling book series is quite possibly the best cinematic adaptation of a Broadway production since Chicago (better than Les Mis, better than In the Heights, waaaaay better than Cats). Erivo and Grande are beyond perfect in the lead roles of Elphaba and Galinda (respectively), with the former carrying the lion‚Äôs share of emotional weight, but the latter stealing pretty much every second of every scene. The music is amazing, the costuming is outstanding, and yeah, they basically kept everything (and added some more). The CGI is a bit wonky at times, but the practical set pieces are legit astonishing. Overall, even folks who claim to not dig musicals, will probably (almost certainly) dig Wicked. If you do dig musicals, this is THE film to see of 2024.

They will say that when it comes to telling stories that nothing is new. Personally, I would agree. However, to find a way to convey messages in a way that moves people after they have already heard them could be no greater achievement. I am not a critic. I love the results efforts more than I love the results for most things in life. Perhaps one day I will learn to be overly critical of products and not the process, but I doubt that life becomes enjoyable at that point. For me, a non-critic, I can only say that the work which must come from countless efforts may be uncounted but will not go unseen for this film. I did not finish it in my first sitting, but fortunately I bought it. I would say I loved it, but that would be redundant. I love everything. So, to escape from repeating myself I would only say congratulations to an almost infinite number of moments that it must have taken to produce the display of talent. A culmination of pure effort and it shows. Although the world changes, the stories that define our struggles, our triumphs and out achievements are on full musical display. I am very impressed by both the onscreen display of effort and without any understanding of what it must take in reality to produce am simply very glad that I decided to purchase the movie. Not just for the idea, not just for the story but to help them celebrate their achievement which my opinion may not matter in the long run, but their effort will inspire people for generations to come. I could not imagine the pressure one would feel striving to be considered in such a way as in the same realm of work as the Wizard of Oz. I would never engage in the argument for the works are in two different worlds and generations apart. But as far as deserving the consideration there is no doubt that the effort of all involved is apparent and deserving of praise and recognition. So, I wrote this review. I like the movie, I bought the movie, and I will watch it again. Thank you.

Middle-aged man / movie buff here: zero knowledge about the franchise or the hype, very low expectations, allergic to the genre, went with my daughters just because they wanted to see the film. But to say I was pleasantly surprised would be a huge understatement. That was actually an awesome film! The music is obviously great, but the highlights for me were the pacing, it doesn't get bogged down at any point, the writing, which is witty and entertaining, and the chemistry between Glinda and Elpheba. Especially Glinda was absolutely brilliant! I can't wait for the second part. I'll still be going with my daughters, but this time it won't be them dragging me to the film.
Wish they'd make movies like they once did. Just entertainment no agendas !

So. Good. Seriously, everything I hoped for and more. Cynthia Erivo absolutely killed it, and Ariana Grande was low-key hilarious. She was so good. I'm a sucker for a musical with strong songs and I've never seen Wicked in any form and only heard the music in passing over the years. And let me just say, this really delivered. The music is simply powerful. Some of the best musical numbers I've heard in a long time. There's real emotion in the songs. It's commendable how they took what by all accounts is an epic, famed Broadway musical and, as far as I can tell, did it so much justice. I was completely hooked. Just, wow.
It was a good movie. Probably better in a theater than on a small screen, but definitely worth watching!
